review.title: $\ell_1$-K-SVD: A Robust Dictionary Learning Algorithm With Simultaneous Update
review.abstract: In many image processing applications, we encounter the problem of suppressing noise that obeys a non-Gaussian statistics. It is well known in the signal processing community that, in case of heavy-tailed non-Gaussian noise corruption, $\ell_1$ distortion is a more suitable metric for data fidelity. Dictionary based image denoising algorithms existing in the literature are typically aimed at minimizing the $\ell_2$ distortion metric, and hence not suitable for suppressing non-Gaussian or impulsive noise. In this paper, we develop a dictionary learning algorithm by minimizing the $\ell_1$ error. The proposed algorithm exploits the idea of iterative minimization of suitably weighted $\ell_2$ error. We refer to this algorithm as robust dictionary learning (RDL). We demonstrate that the proposed algorithm results in higher atom detection rate compared to the state-of-the-art $K$-SVD algorithm, both in case of Gaussian and non-Gaussian noise contamination. For real images, we observe clear superiority of the proposed RDL algorithm over its $\ell_2$ based counterpart, namely the $K$-SVD algorithm, in terms of the quality of denoised output.

INTRODUCTIONIMAGE denoising has been a field of research for several decades and continues to represent a challenging task with advances in imaging modalities. Recently, attempts have been made to effectively solve the problem of denociation through dictionary-based algorithms. The basic idea behind such approaches is to develop a dictionary that is able to present image patches parsimoniously in order to be more precise by using sparse representation. In many applications, the assumption of gaussianness of noise might not hold in reality, making the "2 minimization based algorithms inapplicable. In addition, these algorithms may lead to an excessive smoothing of the image, leading to serious loss of detail in the images.

sections.heading: A. Review of recent literature
sections.text: Some of the initial contributions to the problem of dataadaptive dictionary learning were made by Aharon et al. [5], [6]. They proposed the K-SVD algorithm, which is by far the most popular and successful algorithm for dictionary design. They successfully used the K-SVD algorithm to solve the problem of image denoisation [6], in particular to eliminate additive white Gaussian noise. They proposed two training options: (i) training on a corpus of clean image fields and (ii) training on the noisy input image itself. As the K-SVD algorithm is not suitable for dealing with large image patches arising from large computer requirements, it was proposed to enforce thrift. The KSVD algorithm uses the '2 distortion metric as a measure of data fidelity.

The motivation behind using "1 metric as a measure of data fidelity is to achieve noise immunity and alleviate the problem of smoothing texture and edge areas in images. Experiments with synthesized data sets show the superiority of the proposed algorithm over its" 2-based counterpart, the K-SVD algorithm, in terms of the removal of the recovered dictionary from the basic truth.
